No fault divorce is why it\u2019s so bad, and it was promoted as an equalizer for women, but it ended up hurting women very badly. \u201cBack then\u201d, if they had troubles or tough times, they just hung in there and tried to make it better. Now they just bail.", "As of this morning we are married once and still for 15,146 days, over 41 years. We have had life challenges that statistically say we should most likely be divorced. Yet we are together and happy.\nMarriages don\u2019t just happen, they are build by two lovers who choose to build a lifetime of love together, one day at a time.\nNot all marriages are built to last.\n\u201cBack in the day\u201d people endured miserable marriages because they had fewer options to leave each other.\n\u201cBack in the day\u201d there were far greater social and religious stigma associated with divorce.\n\u201cBack in the day\u201d the typical single male income family wasn\u2019t conducive to security of the wife and kids, so divorce had higher risks and more endured.\nWe must stop looking at divorce as some sort of dismal failure that shows weakness or lack of morals. Love is most often a mistake, most people have multiple failed relationships before they choose to marry. We should look at those who failed and parted as courageous for leaving unhappiness and seeking better, not as failures.\nLove an marriage is a choice.\nHappiness is a choice.\nMentality has changed with more media and more social connections.\nThe modern world markets for profit with unhappiness as a tool. Someone always has better or more if you take social media seriously.\nPeople buy and sell houses more often than \u201cback in the day\u201d. A majority want bright shiny and new, a minority will maintain and renovate their first home for decades. House needs a new roof? Time to sell and buy a new house.\nWe lack long term vision, we\u2019re afraid to dream with our lover because we feel doomed to fail. If we lack long term vision we never build a solid foundation for our love.\nMost of all, we have developed a concept that we find love, that love is something magical that appears one day and fixes our world for us.\nThe truth is that lifetime lovers build love, one day at a time, for a lifetime.\nOur secret to a lasting marriage: Peter Ratcliffe's answer to What are the first signs that make you understand that you are falling out of love with your partner?", "There have always been many bad marriages, many okay marriages, and only a few marriages that stayed really good over multiple decades.\nOne difference is that today two people who are in a bad marriage can end it and get a divorce. This used to be considered very bad.\nIt is likely that romantic movies have given people an unrealistic notion of what marriage should be. This has probably contributed to a high number of bad marriages, or at least bad relationships.\nOne counter to this is that the ability to have sex before marriage has reduced the pressure to rush into a marriage. This has probably allowed many bad relationships to end before they turn into a bad marriage.\nPutting this all together I do not think that there are any more bad marriages today than there has always been. I think there are just more people who are willing to end a bad marriage by getting a divorce.", "Marriages don\u2019t last as long as they used to because we are finally starting to see some progress on getting people out of abusive relationships. Marriages used to last longer because people had no choice - they were stuck with their spouse no matter what. Now people can leave bad relationships.\nThis is unequivocally a good thing.\nWe have also changed the role of marriages. They used to be business decisions - people joined together for property reasons and alliances[1] . Even having children had property reasons - we started handing our property down through inheritance, so we started controlling the context under which children were born.\nYour spouse was merely your business partner in that one of you provided children and the other provided resources for your survival. Or you both cooperated on providing survival resources (farm families, for instance, had both spouses working equally as hard on the farm, along with the kids and the grandparents and any other extended relatives and hired hands they could get to help). You didn\u2019t have to like your spouse all that much, you just hoped to get along with them.\nBut these days, relationships are so much more than that[2] . People get married for love. They get married for companionship. Your spouse is supposed to be your Everything now - your best friend, your lover, your confidante, your spiritual advisor, your co-parent, your business partner, your therapist, your activity partner - everything! Very few relationships can meet such high expectations for very long.\nSo relationships don\u2019t last \u201cforever\u201d because we expect too much of them. The higher your expectations for a relationship, the less of a chance it has to continue and that chance decreases over time.\nWhich brings us back to divorce being a good thing, because you can leave a relationship that isn\u2019t making you happy.\nAnd the final reason why marriages don\u2019t last as long now as they used to is that people who ask that question tend to be very ethnocentric. They\u2019re seeing \u201cmarriage\u201d through the lens of what it means today, in this time, and in this culture. it was much easier to get married \u201cuntil death do we part\u201d back when your spouse was probably going to die in their 50s. And not every culture has the same requirements for marriages. Some cultures don\u2019t recognize anything that we would call \u201cmarriage\u201d at all. Some have them for the duration of child-rearing. Some have built-in time limits. Some allowed divorce \u201cif the man is repulsive\u201d or if the woman is \u201cobnoxious\u201d.\nOn top of that, divorce rates have actually dropped. Whenever no-fault divorces become legal in a region, the rates jump up as people who were previously trapped all rush to get out, but after all of them finally make it out, the divorce rates drops back down to \u201cnormal\u201d.[3]\nIn other words, this is sort of a cross-cultural form of confirmation bias - you\u2019re seeing things that confirm your biases and not seeing the things that don\u2019t confirm your bias because you are only familiar with your own culture.\nBut the biggest reason is that we just made it easier for people to end relationships that aren\u2019t working for them. This is a good thing.\nFootnotes\n[1] Stephanie Coontz: Do you take this man? No thanks\n[2] Five myths about marriage\n[3] Opinion | Divorce, No-Fault Style", "They last just as long, only these days, women can leave their abusive husbands.", "Well back in the day is a little vague but I get the gist of what you are asking. When my father was young his father worked for the same employer for over 40 years, made a decent living so his mother never had to work. Fast forward to today, its a two person income in order to survive and this puts a great stress and strain on the relationship. Another thing is people are less religious now than they were then. Women consider it cheating or feel that they\u2019re inadequate, while men consider it harmless and naturally keep it private, since having others view it causes shame, and have no objection to their wives watching it. I looked up to realise that my darling husband had found the video for me. I was tickled and delighted and started singing even more exuberantly. While I happily crooned and waded through the leaves, teaching my son how to pluck the leaves, the songs that were playing happened to be after my own heart. Each one was from my list of \u201cI love this one!\u201d\nFrom Cranberries to Bobby Darin to Rafi Sahab (sir), the songs just kept getting better and better. I marvelled at my luck and said, \u201cWow, amazing! All of my favourites are playing. It\u2019s just my day!\u201d\nHubby sat quietly with his laptop while son piped up. \u201cMamma, Papa has selected and queued these songs for you just now. That\u2019s why you are seeing all your favs.\u201d My technologically challenged mind hadn\u2019t realised this and I was embarrassed at my gaffe. But it hardly mattered then.\nI was surprised that hubby knew what songs I liked. As in, every song was special and it was amazing that he had selected them from various genres to play them for me. I asked him how he knew about the songs I loved. I don\u2019t remember telling him about them. I don\u2019t even have a dedicated playlist that would give him a clue. He shrugged and told me that he just remembered the songs that I hummed from time to time. Besides, whenever we went on road trips and I launched into some long story behind the song that would be playing at that moment, hubby would make a mental note of it.\nThe lockdown has been manageable for me. But the silence and near absence of life outside makes me feel down at times. Hubby took the spur of the moment decision to create a musical extravaganza to lift my spirits! Not only was the gesture endearing, it was also a revelation to me about how much my hubby knows me.\nI have given a detailed description of a seemingly mundane evening to show how special it became when, despite our responsibilities and confinement, we found a special moment to cherish. The beauty of life lies in small moments. Little experiences add up to make everlasting memories. Our contact with the outside world has become limited. And that has made us treasure each moment even more. Our bond is just getting stronger in the lockdown.\nCircumstances are incidental when hearts are in sync.", "This week started with the usual routine. Until one day I met that person. And guess who it was, someone with BPD. I never had known what that was, nor did I know that I had NPD at that moment. And guess what happened. I lost her. Worse than my dreams, a nightmare, and I want to wake up and see it's not real. I'll never love anyone alike. Button line, I think all of us dream of meeting someone passionate. I don't know if it is that borderlines are the most loveable and passionate beings in existence and everyone dreams of meeting someone like them or is it some kind of attraction that there is between people with BPD and people with NPD, as for people with BPD being as human as us all and dream of meeting someone as passionate as them selves as the rest of us do, I don't know if it works out if the other one had the same disorder. The source is convinced beyond any shadow of doubt that each have found their love mate. The relationship quickly progresses into talks of marraige and a long lasting life together. The source believes the deep relationship bonds that have formed will never be broken..\nAdditional information: During the devalue and the discharge phases, the source suffers more abuse, confusion, and tries to understand and make sense of the narcissist's behavior. However, no answers will come from the narcissist. The source is left in pain, agony and anguish to find all the answers, recover and heal.", "Hard is in the mind and emotions of the beholder. It\u2019s hard because you don\u2019t really want to break up, you want the person to become something other than who he is, and you have a dream or a fantasy about who he is that conflicts with the reality of who he is.\nYou want to believe in the possibility of something happening that is not going to happen, and it\u2019s hard to give that up. It\u2019s not about breaking free from the narcissist, it\u2019s about breaking free from the story you\u2019ve built up about him in your mind. It\u2019s about comparing what you want and hope for vs what you have in front of you, and realizing they\u2019re not ever going to be the same thing.\nKeep looking. You choose your path", "Because you're used to the lies", "I\u2019d say the trauma bond or the love bombing at the beginning. As I state in my book, researchers and psychologists have found that unhealthy, or traumatic, bonding occurs between people in an abusive relationship. The bond is stronger for people who have grown up in abusive households because it seems a normal part of the relationship. Initially, there is an intensity not matched in the earlier relationships of the victim\u2019s life with the parent. It is claimed the longer a relationship continues, the more difficult it is for the victim to leave the abuser with whom they have bonded.\nIf the abuse is severe, it can be like Stockholm Syndrome, which is a condition that causes hostages to develop a psychological alliance with their captors as a survival strategy during captivity. These bonds are formed between captor and captives during intimate time together but are generally considered irrational considering the danger endured by the victims.\nPhysical and emotional abuse during childhood is often present in the context of betrayal trauma. Research has found that child sexual abuse leads to significant disruption in one\u2019s emotional life. The degree or severity of the abuse as well as abuse by a caregiver or close relative can influence the response to trauma.\nThe intermittent reinforcement of attention then criticism/demeaning is also addicting. It is important to break free of a narcissist. There can be no good or healthy relationship coming from it. I have some healing techniques that may help. Here is the list. This is the beginning, there are more to be found under my profile.\nHire a therapist that knows about abuse\nScreen them and even interview them to see if they have had clients who have suffered this kind of abuse, as it is really known only if experienced.\nBecome wise on the topic.\nFind out for sure if you are in such a relationship by reading books about the topic, YouTube videos by psychologists, and answers on Quora on the topic.\nLeave safely.\nOnce you have established that you are in such a relationship, set up plans to leave. Go no contact on all social media and all phones and accounts. Do this the same day you leave the relationship. If you have property or children together, hire an attorney.\nPractice being loyal to yourself first\n\u201cThere is never a day where it is better to be in a relationship that undermines, undercuts, manipulates, abuses or takes advantage of us than it is to be \u2026in a relationship with ourselves that\u2019s filled with self-love.\u201d A statement of self-love could be said every day in addition to other ways of caring for yourself such as relaxation, eliminating negative self-talk, taking yourself out to dinner, or putting fun in every day. The statement is pledging allegiance to yourself and honoring your gifts, talents, and goodness. Commit to being loyal to yourself from now on.\nCreate and set Boundaries.\nPractice with friends first but if you\u2019re a people pleaser, setting and sustaining boundaries can seem overwhelming, or worse, impossible. So commit to creating one boundary, and seeing it through. Start small. And remember, \u201cBeing good, as it turns out, isn\u2019t about pleasing. Being good is about being just to others while also being true to yourself.\u201d\nSpend time with yourself for a while until you regain your balance.\nDon\u2019t try to rush out and date or meet lots of new people. You are healing from a trauma and you will not be in any shape to do anything but lean on friends and use some simple healing techniques. Treat yourself as a sick person who is convalescing.\nPractice good self- care.\nThis is related to loving yourself but basically means: get a good night\u2019s sleep, eat well, exercise, and do some socializing with safe and gentle people. A good support network is also recommended or community such as a church, women\u2019s group or even a hobby group.\nJournal.\nThis can be tied to a gratitude journal or just keeping a journal of your emotions and how you have changed over time once you are out of the relationship.\nWalk in Nature.\nThis practice is easy to do--connect to nature, and if a forest is available, take in its atmosphere. Walking in nature is an easy practice that can start with the mountain yoga pose and then walking in nature.\nPets. Borrow or find a rescue pet.\nStroking a cat or dog can be very healing. Support animals are even better. I could not have survived without my support cat. He started gallivanting at night after I healed--a sure sign that I had recovered.", "It\u2019s does not take long for the intensity of a narcissistic relationship to form a traumatic bond. A traumatic bond forged in the fires of intermediate reinforcement locks you in place quickly. the cycle of intermediate reinforcement with the narcissist playing hot then cold, pleasure then pain changes your brain chemistry.\nIt thereafter is not just a cognitive decision to break up with a narcissist there are biochemical anchors that must be dealt with. In short your brain chemistry changed to help you survive the abuse, now your addicted to the narcissist. Things going right with, or acts of kindness from the narcissist is now your fix. And the absence of the narcissist releases stress hormones and generates longing for them.\nIt takes months of no contact to shed your brain of the traumatic bonds and reset you brain to normal. Whatever passes for normal in your life anyway.\nA place to heal from narcissistic abuse:Narcissistic Abuse Survivors Support Forum\nGood luck to you.", "Because there is an underlying co dependency that is causing you to hang on. This type of thinking is representative of many Analyst types, especially INTJs. Linear thinking helps to pull things out of context to explore them. But then, non-linear thinking is needed to add context and see the bigger picture.\nThis linear form of thinking inadvertently spills into INTJs\u2019 approach to romantic relationships. And of course, \u201cwhen applying non-living world systems to the living, we can make mistakes\u201d.\nHere\u2019s some examples:\n\u201cFirst this, then that\u201d mentality can cause some INTJs to delay romance all together. \u201cI\u2019d like to date her, but I have so much to do right now to finish my degree, that I can\u2019t possibly think of starting something else\u201d. In contrast, non-linear thinking recognizes that this is a complex situation that requires non-linear thinking. Non-linear thinking would suggest that one can work on step 1 and step 10 in tandem.\n\u201cIt\u2019s not safe\u201d mentality can dissuade INTJs from trying different things. \u201cShe\u2019s nice, seems interested, and makes me feel differently, but she seems to not be totally transparent and could be hiding something. She\u2019s unpredictable, and if I can\u2019t have complete transparency why bother telling her or fighting for this\u201d. Non-linear thinking would suggest that additional information is needed to make a determination on this person\u2019s character, and that looking at this in a vacuum could produce a mistake.\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t make sense\u201d mentality suggests that something doesn\u2019t fit, so it doesn\u2019t have use right now. \u201cIt\u2019s not obvious to me how I fit in her life, or what she wants from me, so I can\u2019t see this working\u201d. Non-linear thinking suggests that some experimentation is needed, maybe a round of trial and error before concluding on an intuition without experimental data; it says \u201ctry it on, you might like it\u201d.\n\u201cI need to finish the task at hand\u201d mentality can be very good and sometimes it can be a saboteur because it doesn\u2019t allow INTJs to move on from a seemingly unrequited crush and cut their losses. Other times, this steadfastness makes INTJs very valuable for their commitment and reliability.\nMore points could be added, but will conclude by saying that there is nothing inherently wrong about linear thinking, but it has to exist in a bigger non-linear system. We don\u2019t want to apply linear thinking to situations that are non-linear.\nIf you are emboldened by this, go ahead, break order and pursue your dreams, whatever they may be. A little chaos theory might be just what you need to spark the change in you, and in your life.\nSource:\nNora Bateson - Circular versus linear thinking\nHave you succumbed to linear thinking?\nAlso see:\nDeborah Lindi's answer to Is romance truly that difficult for our (INTJ) personality type?", "Hey! And because not everyone openly declares their relationship to be poly, I think that gathering accurate information may be difficult.\nOur anecdotal experience is based on our own contacts and behavior. It seems like it be hard to observe poly relationships unless you either are so inclined, or have good social relationships with them.\nMFF is favored in fictional portrayals, as it reflects a common male fantasy. It can be shown as just a \u201cstraight\u201d relationship with a bonus. It is safe, tame, and fun. Also, it is traditional, in the patriarchal polygamous fashion.\nReality is much more complex. Any mix of sexuality is possible in poly relationships. Because any relationship with MM interactions is called gay by society, an MMF set may appear outwardly as either MF, or MM, to outsiders.\nLive-in relationships are often tied to practical issues. There is only so much room in apartments for groups.\nLots of people in love don't live together. Unless you know them well, you may have no idea about their lifestyle.\nMy own experience is that threesome relationships are about equal between MFF and MMF, with same sex triads less.\nBut an MM or FF couple could have a non-live-in poly partner, of either sex, who is not obviously visible to casual acquaintances.\nThe permutations get more complex with more partners. An answer that can\u2019t be proved right or wrong, so all I have to offer is my opinion.\nNo, I don\u2019t believe it is. Capitalism was never designed to be a scheme to protect health for once-in-a-century problems that only now with global air travel is much more likely to occur more often. The seeds of capitalism were growing long before airplanes were created. In fact, airplane technology is a result of capitalism, so the current global travel environment is also an offshoot of capitalism.\nThe method that most of society has been using to deal with problems of this nature was to put in place a team of experts on health and epidemiologists. The WHO (World Health Organization) is performing an adequate job for most of the world\u2019s coordination in this issue. In the USA (where I am familiar with), we have the CDC, which can call on the help of FEMA, the US military, and other national organizations to provide assistance.\nWe have had a special White House team that coordinated with 40+ international offices that kept a lookout all over the globe for such problems. These experts developed detailed plans to handle as best as they could predict what was needed to be done quickly to fend off the next viral epidemic.\nSadly, Americans were conned into electing a president that knew nothing about science, management, or government, and had no interest in learning anything about these matters. Several years ago most of these offices were de-funded and closed out of ignorance. So the USA had no plan in place, no agency to handle the early warning signs, and no effective leadership. Combined with a refusal to do what needs to be done, our president had even to this day April 10, 2020, failed to place an experienced leader to handle this crisis.\nIf the country that could land a man on the moon could not manage this problem, it seems natural that less developed, less wealthy countries had as much of a chance to effectively manage this crisis. Some have minimized the problem very well (North Korea, Germany, and even China to some degree), most haven\u2019t. I suspect it\u2019s because most countries have leadership that is as incompetent as the USA has in handling difficult problems.\nSo the clear answer was that the current crisis in the USA and many other countries is and was a failure of government leadership in ways too numerous to mention. Forgiveness is emptying your heart of anger, sadness, and other negative emotions related to the injury. Forgiveness is necessary to have a heart and life full of love, hope, and happiness.\nForgiveness DOES NOT mean carrying on with life after the injury as though nothing happened. If the injury is minor and the partner sincerely apologizes and pledges to not do it again, go ahead and carry on with the new improved relationship. If the injury was serious (cheating for example) and the apology and repentance are not sincere, carrying on as before would not be forgiveness\u2014it would be stupidity. If the injury is severe, and the apology and repentance are sincere, it may still take quite a long time to heal the relationship. The relationship certainly can\u2019t go back to the way it was. In that case the relationship can only go forward in a healthy way if the relationship is transformed by serious efforts by the partners to transform their lives and their relationship. When Substances Control | Listly List Here are some good resources to read.", "This question is a heartbreaking one I hear frequently. In short the answer is there is a tremendous amount of selfish and self-centered behavior that results form addiction. How to get it. How to not run out. How to hold withdrawal at bay.\nThese are all very time consuming endeavors. It leaves little time for concern for others. That isn\u2019t to imply addicts don\u2019t love others - they do! And, when they promise to discontinue use because the harm that they are doing others is genuine and sincere, in the moment it is made. But that moment is short lived because of the compulsion to return to using.\nFor the spouse or relation of an addict they are left confused by promises and repeated conversations that result in a return to using only shortly after extracting those promises.\nBecause true love and commitment to another as in a marriage requires a tremendous amount of compromise and consideration of the other persons needs, this makes the addict/alcoholic while in active use a poor selection for that type of relationship. In order to have a successful marriage/relationship you\u2019d have to have the ability to put the other persons needs before your own \u201con occasion\u201d. Without the ability to do this the other partner is often left feeling like they are always making concessions, excuses and ultimately capitulation to the other person and their disease of addiction. It results in anger, resentment, passive aggressive or outright aggressive behavior which eminmates from an extreme sense of frustration and helplessness.\nThere are programs such as Al-Anon or Nar-Anon, counseling, community resources etc. to assist the spouse/partner of an addict. These are advisable. The partner of an addict/alcoholic might often wonder why \u201cthey\u201d need assistance or a program if the \u201cother\u201d person is the one with the problem. The challenge here is that addiction is insidious, an all encompassing. It has the power to swallow a family whole and keep going. To the co-sufferer of someone with addiction, you\u2019ll know that last statement is not hyperbole. Therefore if the addict is incapable of admitting there\u2019s a problem and seeking assistance, it\u2019s good for someone/anyone in the family to acknowledge the problem is likely larger than extracting a true promise of abstinence/reduction from the afflicted and seek outside help.\nAt these programs the spouse/partner of an addict will learn what things, comments, actions that they may be taking that aren\u2019t only not helpful but may be exacerbating the circumstances. They learn about how actions, sometimes referred to as \u201cenabling\u201d are actually prolonging the addiction. Many of us are isolated from those we love and care about because of health concerns. Those of us who are polyamorous may feel even more isolated, since we are probably limited to what partners we can interact with. Us solo poly folks and those who are just dating may not have access to anyone for intimacy or sex. Self-care is important and making sure that not only our physical, but our mental and emotional health are taken care of can be daunting. Add to that, the desire to make sure our partner(s) are taken care of and we may become overwhelmed. What do we do? How can we have healthy sex and intimacy in a time of social distancing?\nNow I realize that much of what I\u2019m going to talk about requires funds and we don\u2019t all have access to do what it takes to do all of it. However, if you\u2019re reading this, you do have internet access and while physical sex and intimacy may be unattainable, social media has made it possible for us to interact in sexy and intimate ways. Self-distancing doesn\u2019t mean zero contact, it just means zero physical contact. Get creative! Find ways to connect with those you desire by other means than in person.\nMost of us are familiar with the five love languages, words of affirmation, time, gifts, acts of service and physical touch. I suggest we start with these. Identify what your love language is (it could be a combination of several. For me it\u2019s time and touch) and what are your partner(s) love languages. Then find ways to fulfill those needs without physical contact (yes, touch is the hard one). For those of use who are isolated, letting our partners know what we need is imperative. What follows are a few ideas on how to get through all this. Share the ones that resonate with you with those who love and care about you. If you aren\u2019t sure what resonates with them, ask. Request that they participate with you in creating a long-distance intimate and sexual connection.\nWords of Affirmation: This is pretty easy. Taking the time to send texts and messages telling your loved ones how important they are to you is a given. You can also go old school and send them a letter or card detailing your desire and love for them. Use programs like Marco Polo to send videos of you speaking to each other. If they enjoy dirty and or sexy talk, make a recording talking to them that they can play during masturbation.\nTime: This means quality time. Find things you can do via social media and other platforms. Playing games, watching movies, watching porn and spending time together, even if it\u2019s online can be enriching and fulfilling. Have meals together, via Skype or Zoom. Set the time and dates and stick to them.\nGifts: While it may seem difficult to give gifts while being distance, remember, Amazon (and others) still deliver. Send cards, small gifts and things you know they\u2019ll love to them on a regular basis. They don\u2019t have to be expensive, just things that resonate with them.\nService: This is a little harder, since much of service is about being physically present. Many of the previously mentioned ideas can constitute service. Also, you can do something like order dinner and have it delivered to them. If you\u2019re not in total lock down you can bringing them dinner personally. And if you are in total lockdown you can make gift certificates of the things you\u2019ll do for them when this crisis is over.\nTouch: This is the hardest of all. And where you can be the most creative. Mutual masturbation, with verbal descriptions of where and how you are touching them. There are some sex toys that can be operated remotely. Buy each of you one and take turns controlling the toys. Send virtual hugs and strokes on a daily basis. I feel isolated from my friends and family. She became my exclusive partner for everything. Is this normal in serious relationships?", "no_of_follower": 0, "respond_collected": 7, "ans_list": ["Well it\u2019s less a matter of is it normal, versus is it desirable and optimal for you?\nSome people love codependency and they enjoy having one partner with whom they do everything with. This is their optimal arrangement and it can be healthy and functional for them.\nIf however you\u2019re feeling starved of space and autonomy, then this is entirely reasonable. If you want to have some activities that you do with friends, or some days you dedicate to family, this is a reasonable need and request.\nOur relationships should not take over our lives, they should enhance them. This means maintaining the things that matter to us, and maintaining our friendships and networks.\nI find it common for couples who move in together to get into this dynamic. Moving in together requires you to alter and adapt your boundaries. If this is not done deliberately- then it is common to have this over-involvement.\nIf you\u2019re slipping into codependency and feel cut of from your networks- be proactive about this. Reserve some activities or times for friends and family. A relationship should never come at the cost of your social network.\nCommunicate your needs and feelings- and let her know that you need some space and time with other people. Let her know it is not a matter of loving her less- it is just you needing to regain balance in your life. Time apart is also an incredible thing for relationships. I see many couples who take the other for granted because they are always around. Giving each other some space and time to miss each other can be useful.\nAnd it is critical to maintain your own independence and autonomy from the relationship. Be interdependent. Have your own life and identity, and share in the things you want the other person to be a part of. Being defined by a relationship can be a very dangerous game. It\u2019s something codependents love, but it can feel like you\u2019ve lost your identity and freedom for others.\nCommunicate. Work on finding a balance between togetherness and separation that is optimal. As a woman- I know that females tend to need that validation that the space isn\u2019t an outgrowth of less love or doubt on your end. Be clear that you still love her and want the relationship- but you also need to have your autonomy and invest in your friends and family. Having that conversation is necessary. Be deliberate about your time together. It is healthy and functional to develop new boundaries as a relationship evolves.", "It\u2019s \u201cnormal\u201d in the sense that it\u2019s very, very common. It\u2019s not \u201cnormal\u201d in the sense that it\u2019s not a healthy way to be in a relationship.\nIsolation is one of the primary tools of abuse. Abusers isolate their victims because if their victims have other people around who they trust and are intimate with, then those other people might be able to convince them to stand up to their abuser or leave them.\nI\u2019m not saying that your relationship, in particular, is abusive. I\u2019m saying that abusers know how important other intimate relationships are, so they seek to cut their victims off from them.\nThe lesson here is that other intimate relationships outside of your primary romantic relationship are important. It\u2019s incredibly necessary to have friends and family with whom you have *independent* relationships from your partner. This doesn\u2019t mean having *secret* relationships, or people in your life that your partner isn\u2019t allowed to meet or know. It means having relationships that, if you and your partner were to split up right now, those friendships would still exist, because you have a connection to them that does not depend on your connection to your partner.\nIt\u2019s vitally important that you start reconnecting with your friends and family again, without your partner, and that she do the same with hers. Again, this isn\u2019t \u201cexclusive\u201d, this isn\u2019t keeping separate lives, compartmentalizing, or hiding anything. But all relationships need one-on-one time. You should be able to have a \u201cboys night\u201d or \u201cSuperbowl Sunday Without The Spouses\u201d or fishing weekends or, hell, I dunno, have your own shopping trips and spa days - whatever y\u2019all did before the girlfriend came along, keep doing them sometimes without her.\nAnd encourage her to do the same with her friends. If she resists, this is a red flag. If she resists hard enough and long enough, but you still want to keep the relationship, you may need the help of a specialist.\nAnd, by \u201cspecialist\u201d, I mean a therapist who is especially trained in working with abusers. Not victims, not couples, *abusers*. Regular therapists are not trained in how to handle abusers, and regular therapy tends to make abusive relationships even worse because the tools that work when two people use them in good faith become weapons when abusers use them. Only an abuse specialist will be able to recognize if your relationship is abusive and have the tools to deal with it.\nIf someone trained in this field says that your relationship is not abusive, just codependent, they can tell you that they are not necessary for your problems and you can find a more appropriate therapist.\nRead Why Does He Do That?: Inside the Minds of Angry and Controlling Men (book) by Lundy Bancroft. This book is written explicitly about male abusers and female victims, so there are some things that won\u2019t apply to your situation, but it\u2019s a good place to start, to look at some of the signs of abuse and how they\u2019re different from other forms of dysfunction in relationships. I\u2019m also told that Emotional Blackmail by Donna Frazier and Controlling People by Patricia Evans are good books, by people who I trust on the subject, although I haven\u2019t read either of them myself.\nRead the book and start by making some social dates without your spouse. Because this question is being asked in the middle of a pandemic, that might be challenging. But you can start hosting Netflix Parties with friends, or playing online games together, or starting up your own Discord chat, or just having an old-fashioned phone conversation (or less old-fashioned video chat) with a friend in a room in your house with the door closed and your girlfriend in another room.\nTell your girlfriend what you\u2019re doing - remember, these aren\u2019t *secrets* you\u2019re keeping - but insist on having your own private time with your friends. Explain it to her once, maybe twice, but don\u2019t keep arguing about it. This is not something you need permission for. You are an adult (I presume - this question was written anonymously), you don\u2019t have to ask anyone\u2019s permission to spend your own time however you want to.\nSo don\u2019t argue about it. State it simply, clearly, and kindly, and then drop the subject after you have explained. If she tries to argue with you about it, especially if she argues multiple times, or each time you try to exert your independence, don\u2019t hold space for her arguing.\n\u201cWe have discussed this and I have explained what\u2019s going on. I am not keeping secrets, I am nurturing my friendships. I am also not going to keep having this conversation. If you try to keep arguing about it, I am simply going to leave the room.\u201d\nIf she keeps arguing, if she picks difficult times to discuss like when you\u2019re trying to get ready for work or she keeps you up late at night so that you miss sleep, if she threatens you with physical harm, with damaged possessions, with locking you out, with any punitive action, if she withholds sex when you go out without her or she offers sex to keep you at home, if she is passive-aggressive, if she goes behind your back to contact your friends about the \u201cproblem\u201d - all of these kinds of behaviours are extremely concerning and point towards abuse.\nHealthy romantic relationships strike a balance between the amount of time people spend with each other and the amount of time they spend on their own things, including work, family, friends, hobbies, etc. Healthy romantic relationships also leave room for productive discussion over conflicts. If you are missing either of these two elements, then start insisting on them in your relationship, and if that escalates the problem, then you probably could use professional assistance.", "it is kinda the point ..You become a team .", "This can happen especially in younger relationships, give it time, it sounds like living together for you both is fairly new, the novelty will wear off at some stage..\nIf you're feeling suffocated it would probably be best if you sat your partner down & talked to her about what your needs are in the relationship, that you need a certain amount of space to be the best you can be, this also allows you to bring fresh & interesting ideas, information etc to the table..\nThe thing is that the whole deal with spending too much time together is just as bad as spending too much time apart..\nRemember, that each couple needs to determine what they both want or need from their time spent together & their relationship.\nThis should all be about negotiation so you both feel your being heard & will be one of many things as a couple you'll have to work through as you continue to map out your journey as a couple into the future..", "Is it normal in heterosexual relationships and heteronormative relationships? In any relationship, this will be a theme from time-to-time throughout your lives.\nI see some answers to this stating that they shouldn't have to \u201ctake care of him\u201d, and yes, this is true. But, strong couples that are emotionally secure will do this for one-another without any thoughts or reservations. And by this, I mean a relationship that is completely stable with no pre-existing dead weight. Ok, what else tell me about her dreams, her hobbies, her values, what makes her laugh and what makes her cry. Describe him/her to me in detail.\nIf you don\u2019t know what you are looking for, how are you going to find it?\n2- They don\u2019t believe they deserve love\nOhhh that fear of abandonment! When you believe deep inside that because you are so unlovable and therefore easy to abandon, you become insecure and clingy. There is nothing so unsexy as being insecure and/or clingy (even to those who are insecure and clingy themselves!). The antidote for this is to cultivate confidence in the belief that you are ok exactly the way you are.\nIf you find yourself constantly putting yourself down and/or afraid you are going to be dump because you are just not good enough, please hire a coach and work through your limiting beliefs.\n3- They lack self awareness\nThere are people who easily can describe with luxury of details their perfect partner and have the conviction they deserve to be loved. Yet they lack self awareness.\nThis means that they don\u2019t (fully) understand the impact of their words or actions on other people. Self awareness requires connection. You must first be able to connect with yourself to then be able to connect with others.\nNote that these factors of \u2018failure\u2019 work for finding a new partner as well as finding a new job.\nWe humans are beautifully imperfect. NeurOptimal neurofeedback software reads and is responsive in real time to the trainee\u2019s brainwaves. It gives feedback through auditory cues when it wants that automatic functioning brain to pay attention to what it\u2019s doing habitually.\nStress is a brain habit of assuming there is danger present when there is none. Below are some useful tips for recognizing your lover\u2019s level of affection in a relationship.\nHere we go.\nThey Love To Make You Feel Optimistic\nThe skill to boost your partner\u2019s self-esteem during a relationship is critical. After all, during any times of significant adversity or sadness, it\u2019s good to know that you have someone who will always attempt to make you feel better.\nThis doesn\u2019t mean they should suck up to you and agree with everything you say. However, a crucial element of your connection should be the respect you have for each other.\nMaybe you\u2019re on opposite sides of the political spectrum, or perhaps you both differ in music taste. Whatever the case, it\u2019s essential to respect each other\u2019s personality and the views in which your partner holds.\nThey Make Eye Contact When Having A Conversation\nThis one is pretty well known. If they are making consistent eye contact throughout the conversation, it tends to suggest that they enjoy spending time with you, and remain emotionally invested in the discussion.\nIn contrast, those who may be on their phones while talking, or continuously looking away may have their mind pre-occupied with something else.\nThey Want To Be Affectionate\nSome people are nervous about showing public displays of affection (and that\u2019s okay). However, when you are spending time alone with each other, their body language can tell a lot about their emotions towards you.\nQuoting an article written by Jeremy Nicholson Ph.D. in Psychology Today, positive body language can include \u201cleaning in towards you, feet pointing towards you and wiggling happily, legs uncrossed and comfortable, arms open and palms up, playfully fondling jewelry or hair, smiling, extended eye contact, or looking down shyly.\u201d\nIf your partner is frequently displaying any of the above body languages, it\u2019s an optimistic sign that they genuinely care about you.\nThey Passionately Discuss Memories\nThe majority of couples around the world tend to enjoy speaking fondly of memories such as a vacation or day trip. That is bound to spill over into a relationship. Then you have all of the mental aggravators that take hold: loss of identity, self-confidence, self-esteem and eventually self-worth before despair sets in.\nIn addition to financial problems, there are the difficulties with being able to have any quality of life. You can no longer do the things you enjoyed or the things that are necessary to continue life as you knew it.\nAdd to all of that, fear of the unknown\u2014an unknown future. What will that be like for you and your family, for your community and the country? We may feel that boundaries are unnecessary because our partner is supposed to already know and act on our needs and wants, or that they ruin the relationship or interfere with the spice. In reality, all healthy relationships have boundaries! A relationship can\u2019t be healthy until both partners communicate their boundaries clearly, and the other person respects them. Healthy boundaries in a relationship don\u2019t come naturally, nor do they come easily.\nEstablishing healthy boundaries in a relationship allows both partners to feel comfortable and develop positive self-esteem. In order to establish boundaries, you need to be clear with your partner who you are, what you want, your beliefs and values, and your limits. A lot of times, we tend to focus on adjusting to others, taking time away from focusing on ourselves. Many people make excuses for the poor behaviour of loved ones and this is a way to reduce the culpability in a cheating partner. That common denominator is you! From one relationship to the next, you're still you. It's just the way you engage with guys, its your personality that stays pretty much the same. As you get more serious with your new boyfriend, as time passes, you'll naturally stop having those de-javus about your past boyfriend.\nBasically, you're just learning more about yourself and how you perceive and behave in relationships. Its also very surprising if you can view all the relationships between other people from the outside as you'll notice how alike we all are compared to others.", "It is the same YOU, what do you expect.", "Q > Is it okay if I feel like I'm behaving with my boyfriend the same way I used to behave with my ex? I feel like I flirt with him and treat him the same way it\u2019s weird!\nI\u2019m not sure I\u2019m following\u2026\nYou\u2019re asking whether it\u2019s okay to treat your boyfriend the same way you treated your ex when he was your boyfriend?\nSeems to me that if both guys are \u2018into\u2019 the things you do? Then obviously there\u2019s no problem.\nCourse, not everyone has the same preferences so there are going to be cases where one person would be totally into certain behaviour while it\u2019s a complete turn off for the other.\nTo which end you shouldn\u2019t be asking Quora, but you should ask your boyfriend.\nEspecially people with limited relationship experience will inherently end up doing this.\nBecause your entire frame of reference is built up around a limited sample size. So you pretty much can\u2019t know whether what you\u2019re doing is good or not. Or even if there are alternate options unless someone presents them to you.\nThere are going to be pretty solid examples where something you did with an ex either is something you did because you both were inexperienced and didn\u2019t know better. It\u2019s the future and the now. If you can\u2019t let the past go, and if he is unlikely to change, your future will look like the past.\nThen, since you don\u2019t need a toxic relationship, it\u2019s time to let it go.\nIf you both have somehow changed so that toxicity does not arise again, and you both have a commitment to be great with each other and make an awesome life together, then continue it.\nBut if it\u2019s just continuing the familiar instead of a \u201cHeck Yeah!\u201d then go find something better.", "The patterns that made the relationship toxic continue to resurface.\nThe pain surrounding the past consistently interferes with your capacity to be present/be positive. If you haven\u2019t healed or had enough distance from the apex of toxicity- then the freshness of the feelings can spoil any potential to resolve the relationship.\nEnd it if one person is pulling all the weight. Healing a relationship needs to be mutual. It cannot be one sided. This just generates new layers of toxicity.\nThere is more negative than positive.\nThere are not consistent signs that give you hope/optimism about the relationship. Rebuilding trust and health in a relationship takes a LOT of effort. There needs to be patience and understanding that healing toxicity is not an immediate of quick process. So there needs to be daily investment, and clear sings that both parties are working towards something better.\nThe goals are vague. You need to decide what a healthy relationship looks like, and be very specific about what dynamics need to change. If you\u2019re at 0 (toxic), and want to get to 100 (healthy), then that\u2019s awesome. But define what that \u201c100\u201d looks like, otherwise making progress towards a 5 might be taken as evidence that the work is done. And it\u2019s not. 5 is still toxic if 100 is healthy. So celebrate the baby steps, but don\u2019t mistake a moderately less toxic relationship as a healthy one.\nYou need to be on the same page about what needs to change- both in terms of the dynamic, and how you interact. If one person is stubborn and identifies with their toxic traits- then healing isn\u2019t going to happen. Toxic traits emerge from experience, and they are usually protective mechanisms. So it takes a lot of inner work and healing to resolve. Patience is needed, but the desire to overcome those traits is also needed. If someone doesn\u2019t want to heal- they just want you to accept their toxicity- this is a losing battle.\nIf one partner refuses to take responsibility for contributing or enabling the toxicity. It may be the case that one party feels like the victim. And they may have been victimized. But what needs to change on their end- is to stand up for themselves. To enforce their boundaries. To handle conflict better without submitting. And to not stay attached to the victim identity as a way to gain power through guilting their partner. You cannot identify with the past- use it to inform the present, but don\u2019t bring it with you. But as soon as the relationship in question involves someone in a position of power (parent, step-parent or boss) and someone who lacks power (employee, non-biological child, biological child) then the conflict can be exacerbated. In this case, professional counselling is highly desirable.", "Hard to pull off but many have done it. First find what you do have in common and build from there. Healthy communication means discussions instead of fights or arguments (with rare exceptions), and understanding, listening and acknowledging each other in gentle, loving ways.\nUnresolved personal problems and/or issues going into the relationship. Going into a relationship before resolution of your own issues only complicates learning how to deal with your partner\u2019s.\nGetting married for the wrong reasons.\nMen not understanding women, and women not understanding men. I\u2019ve directly witnessed both situations where one person ACTUALLY gave up on a relationship, and I\u2019ve seen cases where they didn\u2019t give up at all, it was just that they\u2019d lost enthusiasm for various \u201csolution behaviors\u201d they\u2019d agreed to, due to them not working.\nBasically, if someone actually HAS given up on the relationship, there\u2019s only one logical thing to do: move on, just as they are doing.\nOnce a relationship is over, it really doesn\u2019t matter who\u2019s \u201caccountable\u201d for anything about it.\nThink just a little about it: if one person goes off with someone else, will the relationship be healed by them saying \u201cit\u2019s my fault?\u201d No. It might make you feel a little better for a while, but it\u2019s still over.\nAmong my very worst relationships, the one that did the MOST long term damage to me, was the one I insisted on pursuing until I could say for sure whose fault everything was. The second includes praise, complements, encouragement, as well as self-disclosure of feelings, victories, failings, hopes, and fears; and toleration and understanding of the feelings, frailties, and failures of the other. The third includes nurturing, care-giving, emotional support, sustenance, advocacy, and guidance; while providing protection, defense, sheltering, healing, and spiritual support. They are your partner, not your child or your employee, you can discuss things with them, but you shouldn\u2019t ever be in a position of ordering them to make themselves into a different person than they are. If whatever thing you want them to change is a major issue (e.g., drug addiction, being abusive) then you should explain to them the effect that behavior has on you. If you throw it again, I will take it away. Are you finished with your food?\u201d Then, and the biggest step, follow through! Every time! If they throw it again, you say \u201cI gave you your warning, now I\u2019m taking it away\u201d and take the thing away. No further discussion. Your child will learn you aren\u2019t messing around and will not tolerate their behavior.", "It\u2019s normal. Don\u2019t play around with her when she does it, or she\u2019ll think it\u2019s a game. Just say \u201cno. Don\u2019t throw that.\u201d She\u2019ll get it. . . In tiiiiiime. She\u2019s learning and this is part of it. She\u2019s excited that she can make things happen. It\u2019s frustrating, but I suggest you give her tiny amounts of food at a time, more and more as she eats her meal because, as you know, when she\u2019s done, it\u2019s all tossable toys!", "Keep an extremely consistent response. Firmly say \u201cNo.\u201d then say something like \u201c I know you are upset/frustrated/angry but do not throw things.\u201d Take the object away and when she has calmed down a bit, weather independently or with your help, you can offer to objective again. The point is to not have a big reaction, as this is typically fun for children, but to calmly and clearly establish a pattern. It will take a lot of repetition to take hold though so keep at it.", "She should be throwing things, it's how she figures out how her body works.\nlimit her access to food and buy her soft toys, but please, do not restrict her physical development for your convenience."], "topic_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 3, 2020", "question_author": "Nicole Zorkoczy", "view_list": [193, 18, 104, 127, 15, 98, 85, 39, 110], "upvote_list": [1, 1, 0, 0, 0, 3, 1, 0, 2], "name_list": ["Mary Hammond", "Helen Golubchina", "Christina Baublitz", "Shiloh Wilson", "Sage Canton", "Lauren Whit", "Kristen Westerhold", "Mandy Baker", "Ina Plassa-Travis"]}, "478": {"no_of_view": "186", "date_list": ["Apr 11, 2020", "Mar 30, 2020", "Mar 29, 2020", "Mar 29, 2020", "Mar 29, 2020"], "question_title": "Why, even after leaving an extremely abusive, emotionally devastating relationship do I continue to make excuses for his actions and behavior? I\u2019m not stupid so why do I continue this none sense?", "no_of_follower": 4, "respond_collected": 5, "ans_list": ["You do not want to work on yourself, you want to focus on someone else. Let them go and focus on healing your own self. Check out Melanie Tonia Evans. She is a great resource.", "It's called the Halo Effect or cognitive dissonance. I am not a professional therapist so I will try to explain it in layman terms.\nIt happens when you meet a person and immediately form a very favorable opinion of that person. Once your mind has formed this opinion it has difficulty accepting any information that contradicts the initial positive opinion.\nCognitive dissonance is another way to describe this phenomenon. It is when a person believes certain things to be true, and when they have evidence to the contrary they can't accept the alternate facts and will basically lie to themselves in order to be able to accept the new information. For example, in my relationship with my ex; I had always said that if a man ever cheated on me I would leave and never look back. When I discovered he had a personal ad on a popular dating site I didn't want to face the truth and felt torn morally, it went against everything I ever felt to be \u201cright\u201d. I convinced myself (with his help) that it wasn't really cheating, he hadn't actually gone on a date with anyone else. It was \u201cinnocent\u201d flirtation and didn't mean anything.\nOr when he strangled me, it wasn't physical abuse because it only happened once and it wasn't \u201chitting\u201d me. I even said to him it was very close to being abusive and he laughed at me and said he \u201cjust had his hands on my throat\u201d.\nThe narcissist (which is what you were involved with) seems to instinctively know it's human nature for people to form these positive beliefs early in the relationship and have difficulty getting their mind to change that opinion. They lay on the charm heavy in the beginning, they pretend to be the perfect soul mate. They sweep their target off their feet, have the same interests, are exactly, what the target always wanted, even more than the target ever thought they wanted.\nThe abuse starts \u201cout of the blue\" and is SO \u201cout of character\u201d the victim struggles with the shock and accepting this harsh contrast to the man they fell in love with. It might be easier to accept if the change of behavior was consistent, but it isn't. The narcissist will go back to his sweet loving self as if a switch went off. The victim excuses the bizarre behavior by chalking it up to the N having a bad day, or finds some other plausible excuse. Over time the abusive behavior gets more frequent and the honeymoon period is shorter. The abuse becomes unbearable and constant (even during the worst times of abuse the narcissist will still out of the blue do something totally unselfish and sweet). Whereas before the sweet and loving treatment by the narcissist was the norm interspersed with bouts of abuse; now the usual treatment is abusive with occasional loving gestures. The victim is so used to be treated poorly that the smallest insignificant nicety is exaggerated in the victim\u2019s mind. Something as simple as complimenting the victim or buying them a chocolate bar will be enough to give the victim hope that the sweet man they met is still deep inside and if they can prove their love or explain how they feel in a way the narcissist will understand; all will be well again.\nPeople often think they can't help obsessing about something. \u201cMy mind just goes there, I can't stop thinking about him/it.\u201d But the truth of the matter is; our brains only know the information we put in there. We control what we think about. The problem is, the mind builds pathways that get deeper the more we think about something. So over time our mind will automatically go to certain thoughts.\nThink about when you start a new job, you have to take notes to remember what to do, or when you are learning to drive, nothing comes automatically, but it doesn't take long before you do things without even thinking about it. It comes naturally.\nAs it is with the narcissist, thoughts of him, those pathways to the brain are so deeply imbedded, you don't have to consciously make yourself think about him, it's automatic.\nIn order to stop thinking about him in all his glory, you have to consciously make yourself think of something else. It might help to take up a new hobby, do charity work, if you know intellectually that you are making excuses for bad behavior, you have to force yourself to acknowledge what you are doing and correct your thinking. Eventually it will stick. But it will take time. Be patient with yourself. You have, for all intent and purposes been brainwashed and are suffering in much the same way POW's do.\nIt is imperative that you remain no contact because those pathways are so deep that any contact with him will take you right back to doubting yourself and questioning if you imagined the abuse. It can be years later, and the narcissist will pop back into the victims life. The victim thinks they are healed and can handle seeing him but it's like riding a bike; you never forget and can easily fall prey again.", "Because you are a victim.\nFinding a therapist or support group can help you transition from victim to survivor.", "You have unfortunately been conditioned to do this. The abuser was able at some point to make up excuses for the behaviour (which you accepted as the truth and forgave) By doing so, a split person (of the abuser) gets created. Casting doubt in your thought patterns, by making you doubt yourself with trying to make sense of the abusive situation (the why). This then conditions you to fill in the blanks for them, you basically can't comprehend that someone would do those things to you, because you are not abusive yourself. The best thing to do is walk away and not make sense of it, don't trust anything that they are doing or saying either, as there is awlays a hidden motive along the line. Practice being mindful of your thoughts and learn to not try to control the outcome of their actions.", "Because you have been subconsciously programmed by that person to do so.\nJust move on from him. This leads to either a determination to continue breaking down the relationship, or a renewed desire to salvage it.\nSocial phase: the focus now lies on the wider processes involving the couple's social networks. The breakup becomes public. Partners will seek support and forge pacts. Factions are formed, mutual friends have to choose sides. This is usually the point of no return\nGrave-Dressing phrase: once the relationship is dead they will bury it, by spinning a favourable story about the breakdown for other people. Many functions.\nOr not.\nDepending on what you think a \u201cfunction\u201d is and how much it must be able to be separated from other human concerns, to qualify as such.\nDepending on whether you consider engaging in \u201carguments\u201d to be legitimate, morally permissible, intellectually productive, socially useful, pragmatically efficacious, and so on.\nAn argument can:\nBe a way to show off your intelligence.\nExplain and promote your beliefs and opinions and make them sound rational and perhaps inevitable.\nScore points in a debate competition.\nLook like you know what\u2019s going on.\nShow people who\u2019s boss.\nShow people that they are not the boss.\nExpress power to person A in order to score respect, adulation, or even affection from person B.\nCompete to define what things mean or what people ought to do.\nSuppress other people\u2019s ideas that you think are inferior to yours.\nBamboozle someone into doing what you want.\nDistract people so you can avoid doing something you don\u2019t want to do.\nExpress frustration or anger in the guise of some other marginally relevant topic.\nParticipate in some kind of \u201cculture war\u201d or some group\u2019s mission of \u201ceducating\u201d the public.\nI recommend viewing the following \u201cexplainer video\u201d to understand Argument in layman\u2019s terms.\nArgument Clinic - Monty Python's Flying Circus", "Yes suffering own illusion of separation\nJudgement Out is reflection of judgement of self within oneself shift perspective from to you or by you into For you and Love yourself unconditionally \u2764\ufe0f\u2763\ufe0f\ud83d\udc9e Love in Spirit Light \ud83d\ude4f\nYour power is inner peace you give up your power for attachment of Ego lack of or access of false self identification\nMeditation Prayer yoga in essence same stillness of mind non judgement identification of energy in present moment is awareness in acceptance gratitude compation forgiveness kindness is transendance\nAcceptance is key in humbleness lightheartedness child's wonder is innocence acceptance is key\nYou reap what you sow", "The precondition for conflict resolution is to assume that, deep down, both sides want the conflict to be resolved - under certain conditions. A dog barking at the end of a chain, or behind a fence, might serve a function. But only the length of its chain, resp. the integrity of the fence, will have any real influence on the outcome. Most of the time its barking is annoying, at best.", "I don\u2019t know what sense of \u201cargument\u201d you are talking about. The topics chosen to qualify the question are quite broad.\nIn logic, an argument is a function, it doesn\u2019t serve a function. Anyone who does any basic program will easily understand this. You will give your program a number of cases, and when those cases are satisfied, you will tell it to do such and such. That is a function in the form of a logical argument. In logic, we define a valid argument very precisely as a structure whereby, if the premises are true, the conclusion cannot be false. This is not the same meaning as when you might use the term \u201cargument\u201d in other contexts.\nIn debate, \u201cargument\u201d might be ambiguous between a disagreement or the different positions taken by the debaters, or it could refer to the logical definition of \u201cargument\u201d as in specific arguments given for their positions which can be analyzed for their validity and soundness. I suppose in this sense the point, or function, of either sense of argument is an attempt to get closer to the truth, or at least better clarify positions on a topic.\nIn the most common sense, let\u2019s call it the domestic sense, \u201cargument\u201d could refer to any verbal fight, dispute, or disagreement between two or more people. In this sense, I always recall that two headed creature from the children\u2019s program Sesame Street. The one head only says \u201cYup yup yup yup..\u201d, and the other responds, \u201cnope nope nope nope nope nope.\u201d And it goes on and on like that. That kind of argument is obviously unproductive. But what makes it such?\nIn the first logical case where the argument is the function, it is doing something for us, namely whatever we have constructed it to do. It produces some desired result. In the debate sense, the desired result is a little more abstract. We have to refer to very general things like \u201cgetting closer to the truth\u201d or \u201cclarifying our positions\u201d. The debate serves its function in as much as we feel it has achieved these more general abstract purposes. I may have underplayed a purpose in the domestic sense, or lessened it by poking some fun at it.\nIn reality, common domestic disputes may have the same general purposes as a debate. But that really depends on the persons involved, and what they want to get out of it, and whether they want to get the same thing from it. If the one person has the sole purpose of clarifying contrary positions on a topic, and the other genuinely wants to get closer to the truth, the first person is going to really annoy and frustrate the second. It\u2019s going to appear that they are merely playing devil\u2019s advocate, and not genuinely attempting to find a common resolution. Just as in a piece of code, or even in a formal debate, those arguing in a domestic dispute ought to first decide their purpose, and agree on a desired outcome. Obviously that is very difficult to do in the course of life since these disagreements can seemingly erupt almost spontaneously out of raw emotions and not decidedly well formed logical propositions. But as soon as one feels like the argument is going nowhere, that it is become just like that two headed \u201cyes-no\u201d Sesame Street monster, it\u2019s probably time to take a step back and start considering the purpose. Then when emotions have cooled, discussing the desired outcome with one another to see if you can at least get on the same page on that. If not, the argument will serve no function, even when it is in a perfectly valid logical form.", "If you are a goat n the listener is a Woolf, arguments won't, if you are a jaguar and listener is a woolf you need not to argue.your power has already functioned.might is right", "Yes. They sort out disputes", "Yes and no. Of course, like many good things, they can be taken too far and lead exactly to the thing we were arguing against in the first place: an argument about war leads to war and an argument about rape leads to rape because they are coerced into trying to prove eachother wrong and it becomes more violent and boom! We have a war.\nOne could argue that arguing is the source fo humanity. Arguments can be observed by an outsider, and they teach each other about the opposite point and maybe people become convinced of a much more positive point. Every couple has , unique requirements of space . There are couples who can co exist peacefully without arguments & then there are couples who engage in argumentative conflict . But space requirements vastly vary . By space , I mean physical distance for some hours of a day & head space .\nIf one looks at physical distance , it is one of the healthiest , and best ways of avoiding conflict . Unless people choose to dial their partners or argue over social media , text messaging or video calling .\nThese basics known , one of the best the golden rules of all relationships is ; Do not be in each other\u2019s face 24/ 7\nA lockdown situation restricts mobility . But there are little tricks to avoid arguments . I\u2019m listing them in brief points .\nRoutine - A lockdown offers people the \u201c work from home \u201c which reduces travel time . However it\u2019s very important to get good sleep , wake up at a fixed time , like one is used to whilst working from one\u2019s workplace . Sleep and routine are extremely effective to combat stress , even so in the abscence of calming techniques like yoga , meditation, movies , music or reading. Get enough sleep , do not make the mistake of having no routine . This shall put you in your worst moods . Draw up a routine\nWork in separate rooms if possible . If you live in a studio , find different corners .\nCommunicate only as much as you would during a normal work day . Remember you and your partner are working from home .\n4. Do not talk only about the pandemic - you are reading the pandemic , living the pandemic . You need to give your mind rest . Talk about good things . This helps .\n6. We will learn to fully embrace our feelings in general. We will experience joy and pleasure with new eyes. We will experience loss and grief with new eyes. We will taste our food completely. We will feel each sensation and emotion and we will savor.\nThis disease may very well lead the masses to a new mindset regarding tolerance. We live in an extremely diverse yet very intolerant world. Yet when one cannot breathe, we are all alike. We are all the same. We are all human beings. We may become more empathetic as a society.\nWe will learn to appreciate our senses. Touch, taste, smell, sight and hearing. Each experience we have will have meaning and won\u2019t be taken for granted.\nWe will learn to connect with G-d in a deeper, more meaningful way. We will, as a society, come to realize that each day and each experience we have - however briefly - is actually a gift. We will learn simple gratitude.\nWe as a society will realize that the \u201calmighty dollar\u201d isn\u2019t important. Not really. Not when you cannot breathe. BUT by going through this, I was made whole and my eyes opened to truth and clarity that has made me surpass any \"potential\" or level that I ever imagined.\nI found out that the one who you think is the closest to you, who is supposed to be your biggest fan and protector, can be the person to inflict the most volatile and destructive hurt on you that you may experience in a lifetime.\nI found that I always saw the good in people and that there is real evil in this world and that it hides behind the most charming smiles and flattering words.\nI found that I never protected myself as I should have, and that boundaries are necessary in life in order to prevent being taken advantage of by others.\nI found out that my childhood was not as happy as I told myself it was, and that the main reason I got entangled with a toxic man was because my father was one.\nI found out that I have a plethora of amazing and wonderful things to offer this world, my partner, and my family, and that I need to share them and protect them at the same time.\nI found out that I have a never ending supply of love to give out, but that I need reciprocity in order for it to work and for both of us to reap the benefits and rewards that come in a healthy relationship. (and oh how many rewards and benefits there are!!:))\nMost importantly, I found out that I really love this girl I have become. I love where I came from, because it made me who I am today, and I love that I now have a story that can be used to help others and to possibly prevent someone from going down the same path that I did.", "The way someone treats you is not reflective of your worth or value. Value is an entirely subjective concept. You may have 100 amazing qualities, but those qualities will not be valuable or admirable to some people. And that\u2019s okay. A bad relationship where you felt unappreciated does not reflect your lack of worth. I learned that many people love and admire who I am, and what I offer. And someone\u2019s rejection or devaluation of you is an indication of what they admire and want- it is not a reflection of your lack.\nWe are much stronger than we realize. That relationship put me through a lot, and after it ended- I realized how adaptable I am. How resilient I am. That I have an incredible capacity to learn and grow. I thought I\u2019d never heal or recover from that breakup- and it was so reassuring to see the gradual growth. I came out of that relationship with more wisdom, experience, and strength than I had going into it. So it was inspiring to feel the daily healing and growth after the relationship. You make it work.\nI believe that choosing to marrying someone gives a degree of security that nothing else will ever match up to. That is because both of you are actually deciding to be bounded officially by law (and also social standards), that you agree to be exclusive to each other for the rest of your lives. My literature teacher once joked and shared that marriage is like eating cheeseburger. You better make sure that the cheeseburger is awesome because imagine eating that same cheeseburger for the rest of your life!\nBut that said, apart from marriage, people have a very wrong concept of \u201cdoing something major\u201d to make things work. We have always loved intensity. Just like how we wait for an entire season before we watch a TV series; or how we crash diet over a week and hope that it works out for our weight loss. It usually doesn\u2019t last.\nThe opposite of intensity is actually consistency. Just as how brushing your teeth 3 mins twice daily works wonders compared to just visiting the dentist once every 6 months; or how working out 30 mins daily for the month will yield results compared to doing 14 hours at one go. The same applies to relationships as well. It wasn\u2019t a specific thing that your partner or you did for each other that was the turning point (though there a rare exceptions), but it\u2019s those little things like waiting for your partner to finish their work before having a meal with them; or deciding to try out snorkelling even though you don\u2019t really like the ocean.
