You didn\u2019t know you would be with some raging drunk who drinks irresponsibly.\nTo be honest this blaming and refusal to take accountability for his actions is an indication of how this is going to hurt you in the future and open a possibility for physical abuse, since what it looks like here at the moment is currently mental abuse.\nI think the problem that stands out to me is how his future wife has just said this is something that makes her uncomfortable, and now he\u2019s provoking her to behave like a lawyer to try and educate or explain a case to him that should come naturally in the first place: if your loved ones are hurt by your actions, you\u2019re supposed to try to fix them\u2026because they\u2019re your loved ones.\ninstead he\u2019s more concerned with dismissing your feelings and doesn\u2019t want to deal with you.\nHonestly, I\u2019ve been in a relationship with an alcoholic before, and sometimes the only thing you can do is walk away because no one signs up for the sleepless nights, babysitting their significant other, and working their ass off for a good future while their drunken significant other actually works against them and tears it down. I would never do it again, and I would say In the long term it\u2019s actually easier and less stress to be single than go through this shit.\nIf he is telling you he doesn\u2019t care about you and wants to drink, then believe him and leave.", "There's absolutely nothing--not one, single, solitary, thing--that you can do to affect your fiance's drinking.\nTher only thing you can do us to ask yourself, how long can I live with this?\n6 months? A year? How about five years? Ten?\nUnless you are positively certain that you could live peacefully with this behavior--not with resentment, not with anger or pain-- don't marry this guy, because he's not going to change. Not ever.\nYou probably hoped that he would. That when you agreed to get married, he'd do whatever was needed to make your lives together peaceful and easy. Just as you would, of course.\nBuy that's not going to happen. He's a drinker, he'll always be a drinker, and he's told you flat out that he wil not change.", "As much as you might not like to hear this, I suggest you listen to him. Not in the sense that you are doing something wrong by wanting him to cut back or drink moderately, but listen to him in the fact that he is telling you. The fact is he is not at all interested in changing. And unfortunately, there is nothing you can do about changing him either. That\u2019s just a fact.\nSo that leaves you with a couple of choices. 1. Learn to live with it. I don\u2019t know your situation, but most folks I have ever met that had a drinking problem usually slowly spiralled downwards towards alcoholism or worse behaviour. 2. Find someone else. The partners come to expect certain things from the other and it doesn\u2019t necessarily mean they don\u2019t appreciate your efforts, it\u2019s just that they forget to mention it. Sometimes, we even \u201ctrain\u201d our partners to take us for granted. We do this by anticipating their wants or needs and take care of things without being asked. If our partner does mention it, we often tend to minimize it. \u201cOh, it was no big deal. I don\u2019t mind doing it.\u201d The way around this is to talk about it. Let your partner know you\u2019d like some acknowledgment for your efforts. Tell them it makes you feel happy when they tell you that they appreciate you. Make sure that you model the treatment you\u2019d like to receive by praising and thanking your partner, too.\nLack of emotion and lack of affection are often the result of a communication lapse. It\u2019s also true that different people show emotion and affection in very different ways. For example, a partner might think they are showing you affection when they shovel the walk before you go to work. If what you really wanted was a hug and a kiss, you\u2019ll probably feel short-changed by the snow free sidewalk. Your partner is going to be confused when you don\u2019t see his act of kindness as an expression of his affection for you. You actually have quite a bit of control of this area because you can initiate a hug without an invitation! You can snuggle up and say, \u201cOh, you just give the best hugs! I feel so loved when you hold me!\u201d You can encourage your partner to be affectionate by being affectionate and by making positive comments when they reciprocate. The other thing you can do is to simply accept that is the way your partner is and try to recognize other ways they show their feelings for you.\nRespect, on the other hand, is nearly impossible to \u201cteach\u201d someone. Treating someone with respect is a tacit understanding that you are both equal in the relationship. Neither party\u2019s status is above the other\u2019s, and both of your opinions and ideas have the same merit. We see the world in terms of our expectations of it. The world \u2018should be\u2019 a certain way, people \u2018should be\u2019 a certain way. We have these beliefs and we expect the world to reflect those beliefs. Often it\u2019s not even conscious. We simply have a kind of mask of perception through which we sift and sort the world so that it conforms to our expectations of it. The only expectations we have any control over - if in fact we do, which is arguable - are our own. We all have the right to set expectations on relationships. We call this \u201csetting boundaries\u201d. It\u2019s healthy, and something we need to learn to do if we hope to have functional and rewarding relationships with people. And we all have our own standards. If you\u2019re willing to accept someone \u201cas is\u201d, then logically you need to accept the fact that they expect certain things from you, and they may have different standards from yours. Face it, it\u2019s very unlikely that you will change them, or that you will change yourself for them. They are what we call \u201cpolar opposite\u201d, meaning they use exactly the same cognitive functions in reverse order.\nINTJ:\nHero: Ni (willpower)\nParent: Te (rationality)\nChild: Fi (moral)\nInferior: Se (physics)\nESFP:\nHero: Se (physics)\nParent: Fi (moral)\nChild: Te (rationality)\nInferior: Ni (willpower)\nBasically, they share similar values in a different degree of importance. Since they are very similar in certain aspects, for instance:\nThey both walk to their own song.\nThey both have a strong inner moral code.\nThey both are all about the results and the performance.\nTherefore, they share high camaraderie for being so similar, yet they have at the same time low compatibility with each other for being so similar. It\u2019s very difficult for them to communicate with each other, for instance\nFor instance, ESFPs unconsciously use non-verbal reading a lot, but INTJs are natural poker face.\nThey will have a hard time meeting each other in the eyes if they have very different values.\nThey are both very individualistic and egocentric.\nThey can sometimes both compete to be the center of attention.\nSince they value things in different orders, that can also cause some tension, by example:\nI find my mother to focus too much on what is good or wrong; she constantly passes on value judgments upon people and is utterly unaware of her own moral transgressions. On the other hand, she reproaches me to be a cold intellectual.\nESFPs are all about subjective truth (Ti trickster) whereas INTJs are all about objective truth (Fe trickster)\nShe reproached me to be too much in my head (Ni hero) and I reproach here to be too expansive (Se hero).\nSince they both are each other's subconscious; they aspire to be like each other. There\u2019s definitely a great pedagogical relationship between polar opposites, for instance:\nINTJs can learn how to live in the moment (spontaneity) whereas ESFP can learn strategical planning.\nINTJs can learn how to be expressive and ESFP can learn when to actually shut up and listen.\nINTJs can learn to mature their inner feeling and ESFP can learn how to mature their outer thinking.\nThere\u2019s high respect between both types, but I would recommend a casual relationship between both of them. The \u201cshould\u201d in this question is a bit of a misnomer.\nKnowing about your partner\u2019s past does teach you a lot about them. It can tell you who they\u2019ve usually been attracted, why their relationship ended, and what you can expect in a relationship. Additionally, they may share stories of how they\u2019ve grown or what alterations they\u2019ve made when it comes to approaching romantic relationships.\nSo in a way, a general knowledge about your partner\u2019s past can be useful, and it can offer you insight into their experience, and possibly foreshadow what to expect.\nHowever, if you want to know about their past in detail- and if you are the type to overthink, self-doubt, and are easily made insecure- then knowing about your partner\u2019s past is not in your best self interest, and it is also not useful for the relationship. While you can listen to their experiences to get an idea of their past- this does not neatly predict how the relationship will unfold.\nSo if you learn about their past and it becomes an obsession, or a point of lowered self esteem- I have seen people manifest the thing that they fear most.\nFor example- if you anticipate something catastrophic in your relationship, this generally means you pull out a bit. You act distant, suspicious, and pre-emptively contemptuous. Or, you may have suspicions when there is no reason to be suspicious. This can create all sorts of unhealthy dynamics.\nSo evaluate your reasoning for wanting to know someone pasts. A final note- is that some personality types are manipulative and controlling. And some partners who have narcissistic traits may pry about your past as a means to control you. If they know what you have tolerated- they will know how far they can push your boundaries. Additionally- I have had clients experience partners who threatened to blackmail them with personal information, or use that information to shame them.\nSo it is again important to be clear about your motives for knowing someone\u2019s past. And it is important to know the ways it may benefit or act as a detriment.\nTo give a personal example- my partner and I once played the \u201c20 question game\u201d, late at night since we couldn\u2019t fall asleep. We both revealed particular details about our past. We both ended up feeling hurt, and knowing information that was really not beneficial to know. Long story short, we can joke about it now- but for a while it became a real point of insecurity- to have particular moments of our previous relationships revealed. I spent a couple of summers working for the Hamilton\u2019s General Store in Lake, and of course walked and hiked around the area. The first summer I was walking back to the dormitory house after a square dance, and I heard hoof steps behind me.\nI walked past a lamp post, and saw a young moose slowly following me down the road. I walked on quietly, and got to the front porch and sat down. Moments later the moose walked up to the porch post and stood there for about a half hour. A little spooky!\nThe rest of the summer, I had what I surmised was the same moose following me on several other occasions, and got used to it. I know that there are hundreds of pictures of me and the moose out there, and no Ranger could help me figure out why this animal was identifying and following me.\nThe next year I was back for a couple months at Lake again, and was hiking along an unused road between there and Fishing Bridge, when a moose comes walking into a clearing I had just traversed, with two almost newborns following her. (Moose quite often have twins).\nIt started walking along following me with babies in tow and stayed quite close, around ten feet behind me, for almost a mile.\nAfter that I had several more occasions of moose stalking, and became quite the photo op with the moose and babies in tow.\nWhile this was a very strange occurrence, I am the first person to warn people to NOT APPROACH ANY WILD ANIMAL. Just in Yellowstone National Park, there are thousands of people injured by interacting with an animal either large, like bear, moose and bison, to a small chipmunk. I never figured out why that young female moose liked following me around, but it never made a move towards me in any negative way.", "No depends on if your dangerous and how you approach them like any other herbivore animal.", "As a Newfoundlander I can safely say moose will avoid you for the most part (but don't poke the bear) but stay away from bull moose during the rut! During the mating season male (bull) moose are extremely aggressive and will attack people in their territory. So be careful in the woods during the rut but otherwise if your not antagonizing the moose it will try to to stay far away from you. Details aside, it\u2019s a human mechanism that allows a person to feel the emotions the opposite one is feeling. This is often unconscious.\nSo if your partner is feeling low confidence, you\u2019ll unconsciously feel the same too.", "Yes. Absolutely.\nYou are the average of the 5 people you spend the most time with.\nIf everyone around you is a failure, you will be surrounded by low confidence and pessimism.\nIf everyone around you is successful, you will be surrounded by supportive and energetic people who wish you the best.\nWhich of the 2 life conditions do you think will contribute to your own success/confidence the most? Humans tend to live in our past and our future and forget that the most power and satisfaction comes from living in the present. How do we do that, when we are in the midst of transitioning from a relationship to hopefully a friendship? It\u2019s easy to want to dwell here. Rehashing all the good or the bad. Guess what? It won\u2019t change anything. It\u2019s just going to make you miserable.\nFind one good friend that you can vent to about anything and use them as your \u201cpast regret\u201d friend. When shit comes up, call them. And the most you can vent is for five minutes (which to your friend may feel like forever). Then stop. ( I used to set a timer for myself when I caught myself feeling sorry for myself over relationship transitions. For ten minutes I was supposed to wallow in self-pity and do nothing else. After three or four minutes, I\u2019d start laughing.)\nWhen you find yourself mired in the past, stop and think about all the good things in the present. No matter how crappy you feel there will be good things out there if you just look. Take the time to write them down, so you can revisit them when you\u2019re feeling stuck.\nForgiveness\nBe forgiving of yourself and the other person. We all make mistakes and we all grow and move in different ways. Seldom is there truly a \u201cbad guy\u201d when relationships transition. Usually we grow apart or our lives take sudden twists and the relationship is no longer what it was. And sometimes that means moving on. Being able to forgive yourself for what seems to be your part in this, is the first step.\nForgiving them is the next. Human beings make mistakes and you and your partner are humans. Don\u2019t make them into an evil person or a hero.\nTake time apart.\nUsually one of the people involved hopeful that there will be some sort of reconnection and that everything will go back to normal. That seldom happens. I\u2019m a huge advocate of staying friends if at all possible when you transition out of a relationship. The best way to do that is to take time to be apart. If both of you are in agreement, set a date for lunch or coffee at least two months into the future. Then meet and check-in with each other.\nOf course if there are kids involved or other things that require you to interact then a different tactic will be needed. The best thing to do in these circumstances is to have only contact as necessary and to take even a few more months before that solo lunch date.\nNothing is forever\nWe get caught up sometime in the fairy tales of relationships and when they are over, we feel like a failure because we didn\u2019t find \u201cthe one\u201d. Which means we negate all the good of the relationship and act as if we\u2019ve wasted our time on the one that just \u201cfailed\u201d. You didn\u2019t fail, you lived. And living has its ups and its downs.\nNothing is forever and we need to remember that the impermanence of life is what gives us a reason to live and explore and to celebrate. Instead of looking at the future with dread, look at it as the next adventure.\nGifts\nEvery relationship brings you gifts. Even the worst relationships bring you gifts if you take the time to look at them. Acknowledge the gifts that you received.\nCelebrate you!\nCelebrate your awesomeness (which is what attracted the former partner in the first place). Know that you are whole and complete just the way you are. That while you may want someone else in your life, you don\u2019t need them.\n\\", "This time is all about you. Find things that make you feel good to do, that aren't vices like smoking or drinking. Do the things you could never do in your toxic relationship. Learn how to love yourself for exactly who you are because you're trying to be the person you want to be. Workout, eat right, treat yourself right. The rest will come in time \ud83d\udc96", "There are a lot of research into this topic. In the field of psychology and in the field of social science.\nMy specialization is social science. "upvote_list": [], "name_list": []}, "450": {"no_of_view": "730", "date_list": ["Apr 10, 2020", "Apr 4, 2020"], "question_title": "How do you use writing to radically improve your relationships?", "no_of_follower": 4, "respond_collected": 2, "ans_list": ["Photo by \u00c1lvaro Serrano on Unsplash\nHey Adriana Moraes ,\nAccording to Stephen Covey, author of \u2018The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People\u2019, the reason why most relationships fail is that we focus on changing our superficial behaviors and attitudes before addressing the way we perceive the relationship itself.\nCan you think about that for a second?\nIt means that we try to handle the symptoms instead of addressing the causes.\nSimply put, instead of getting deeper into our relationships trying to pinpoint what doesn\u2019t feel right, we invest in \u201cquick fixes\u201d hoping that the symptoms will go away.\nBut there is a simple writing framework that I\u2019ve always used in order to deeply build my personal relationships.\nI used to apply this same framework while I was living abroad during which I couldn\u2019t see my girlfriend (now wife) as often as I would like.\nI also used this framework to write \u201cthank you\u201d letters to business partners and colleagues.\nAs we\u2019re talking about maintaining a relationship, I would say there are 2 structures that will design your writing: one for solving conflicts and the other for expressing gratitude.\nHere\u2019s the 3 step process for solving conflicts by writing a letter:\nExpress your feelings without blaming the other person.\nHere you will try to express your thoughts and feelings about the situation but make sure to focus only on your perspective.\nTry to explain how did you feel about the issue without making the other person feel guilty.\n2. Empathize with the reader.\nDo your best to understand the other person\u2019s side. What might they have felt to behave that way? What untold struggles have they been facing?\nBy bringing this up, you\u2019ll make the other person feel important and you\u2019ll both find common ground.\n3. Share support\nYou should say what you expect from this relationship in terms of behavior and support. What can you do to help each other? Are your goals aligned?\nIf you follow these 3 steps, you\u2019ll set a neutral environment to address the issue and the reader will most likely become less defensive.\nHowever, lasting relationships are not only about resolving conflict but also about nurturing.\nSo let me show you how to write a letter to express gratitude and appreciation.\nPaint the scenario\nFirst of all, you should write an introduction to grab the reader\u2019s attention and make him or her want to read the letter.\nHere you\u2019ll write something that you know the person would agree with you, whether it is a background story about what you\u2019ve been through together or a fun fact about your relationship. But the reader has to think \u201cOh yeah, that\u2019s true!\u201d\n2. BUT I would like to add some input on my mental progression with confidence and self-esteem issues as the years have progressed and my physique has continued to improve. I will elaborate on both my prior outlook as the insecure girlfriend, as well as my current outlook.\nAgain, I realize my physique isn\u2019t the cats meow for everyone; I did what I needed to do to attain MY version of the ideal female physique (and I\u2019m still working on it!). It has ALWAYS been about getting to that point where I\u2019m satisfied with my physique (I\u2019m not there and honestly don\u2019t think it will ever come), BUT this question had me stop and rewind time 7 years - back before any of my lifting endeavors. Back when my physique was nothing more than that of the \u2018straight up and down\u2019 of a boy\u2019s body. Back when my confidence was buried under the baggy clothes that worked so well to hide the shame I harbored for my body. Of course, 7 years of time has allowed me to grow into a much more mentally secure person (in general), but I can\u2019t deny that I would have felt vulnerable and threatened if my then-boyfriend 7 years ago would have shown me a photo of some curvy, gorgeous Insta model. It\u2019s true. But it\u2019s quite interesting to analyze how I\u2019M now the one showing my husband photos of these other ladies.\nI\u2019ve never been one who has an easy time holding her tongue. The older I get, the more prone I am to dispensing that stone cold, seemingly heartless line of truth that everyone is thinking but no one else will dare utter. When the idiot spouts off at the mouth, I\u2019m generally the one in the room who will be the first to pipe up. I find this quality exacerbating as the years progress, and I must add that I feel a bit\u2026\u2026 bitter towards most. The reasons are quite numerous, honestly, but there\u2019s one I particular reason that is quite fitting for this discussion. Please pardon me, as this is really turning into a lengthy piece.\nTwo quotes have stuck with me throughout the entirety of my life, and one of them is the following, \u201cThere is no such thing as an ugly woman; just a lazy, uninformed one.\u201d Now please, I KNOW my faults, and my imperfections are too numerous to count. I don\u2019t want to give the impression that I\u2019m rooting my own horn, but holy shit have I put in my time. While in college I scouted for and found a job that would allow me to work minimal hours for maximal dough (a high-school sports photography job). Time was a precious resource for me and every extra hour I had was dedicated to reading. Reading and reading and reading and READING. The journal articles, the pubmed studies, the blog posts by the experts in the field - I was OBSESSED, and was often locked away in the room I rented for 300 bucks (bills included ;) ). I knew what I wanted my physique to look like, and I knew that I knew that I had to put in my time in the books to make my time in the gym the most efficient as possible.\nI was OBSESSED. I knew what I wanted and did what I had to do to make things work. There was no time for the whole pity party of \u2018poor me I\u2019m so insecure and self-conscious.\u2019 My schedule included classes and work, but I MADE time. How? I scouted for a job that paid me $100 per hour. I rented a room from a lady for $300 per month, and often cleaned the rest of her home (and her car and her mother\u2019s home) for deductions in my rent. Often times I was paying $150\u2013$200 in rent, with a total of $400-$600 in expenses per month. Of course this meant that my monthly expenses were paid for by working just a measly 4\u20136 hours a week. I drove a \u201899 Camry so gas was cheap. My only other expense was car insurance. I cut out every other unnecessary expense. Those were the days of using email and facebook to contact people (mooching off free WiFi) since I refused to pay for monthly cell service. My splurging was spending 20 bucks at the local thrift store for a few new shirts, and maybe 5 bucks at a local bakery on Sunday. Sales at the grocery store were my go-to, to the point of even asking if they would just give me their old \u2018no good\u2019 throw away veggies (they couldn\u2019t due to legal reasons. I then countered and said I\u2019ll sign any liability waiver\u2026 nope \ud83d\ude15 lol). I ate the cactus out of my own backyard to save money. I fucking MADE IT WORK. I MADE time for my schooling, my studies (studies meaning gym-related studies), as well as the actual lifting. It has been a long 7 years, but I have scrapped and scrounged every minute to be able to change my life and attain the things I want most.\nI used to be that self-conscious girl. Sure, I still have my moments, and there are some things that can\u2019t be changed no matter how much work we invest. BUT there\u2019s a great deal that we CAN do. You DO have the time- you just aren\u2019t hungry enough to MAKE the time. I mean, its there.", "I know people in healthy, functional monogamous relationships. I\u2019ve also known people in unhealthy, dysfunctional monogamous relationships.\nI know people in healthy, functional polyamorous relationships. I also know people in unhealthy, dysfunctional polyamorous relationships.\nLike any relationship, it depends on the people in the relationship. But in general, I would not assume that a polyamorous relationship is any less functional than a monogamous one.", "No, I do not think poly relationships can function as monogamous relationships. If we settled for that low standard, all our relationships would blow up.\nI know some individual people in monogamous relationships who have happy, healthy relationships. But you do not NEED to have a happy, healthy relationship in order to maintain a monogamous one. Our entire culture is set up to support monogamy, whether it\u2019s happy or healthy or not.\nThe focus on monogamy in our culture is on longevity, not health or happiness. Oh, sure, we pay lip service to happiness, what with relationship counseling and self-help books and all. But the happiness is the *tool* meant to encourage *longevity*. Longevity is the goal here, sometimes at all costs.\nAs long as a monogamous relationships last until somebody dies, it\u2019s considered a \u201csuccess\u201d. This kind of pressure traps people in relationships. We make it harder for them to leave relationships with resistance to no-fault divorce laws, with capitalism encouraging people to pool resources just for survival, with social disapproval for breakups.\nIt\u2019s better to stay together than it is to break up, in monogamy. If you break up, your relationship has failed.\nSince staying together is the *cultural* goal, people don\u2019t really need very good relationship skills because the culture is motivated to support the continued existence of the monogamous relationship. We push people together whether they\u2019re compatible or ready to handle a relationship or not. People learn all kinds of horrible things designed to keep people together and they don\u2019t learn any of the things they need to foster happiness and good emotional health in interdependent relationships.\nPeople do not learn how to communicate. They don\u2019t learn how to listen. They don\u2019t learn the art of compassionate negotiation. They don\u2019t learn how to fight ethically. They DEFINITELY do not learn how to apologize.\nPeople learn things like manipulation and control to get what they want. They learn to feel possessive over other people\u2019s things like their bodies, their emotions, their time. They don\u2019t learn how to respect each other\u2019s agency, in fact they learn explicitly how to DISrespect other people\u2019s agency. People don\u2019t learn empathy. People learn to treat their partners as need fulfillment machines. It\u2019s possible to be monogamous and not do these things, but these things are baked into the culture at a foundational level, and often how relationships stay together in the first place.\nIf poly relationships functioned like monogamous relationships, they would all be doomed. When you add all the shitty things people learn in monogamy and you take away the cultural support pressuring people to stay together (because there is no cultural support for polyamory), and then you pile several relationships like this on top of each other, you get one big mass of dysfunction.\nEven with the cultural pressure to stay together in relationships, monogamous marriages still have an average of 50% divorce rate, with a 100% breakup rate of every relationship that came before The One they chose to marry.\nIf that\u2019s the standard we\u2019re holding relationships to, then yeah, I think poly relationships hold up just fine. We don\u2019t have any statistics on breakups in poly relationships, but my anecdotal observation as a community organizer and educator is that this is about right. Poly people marry and divorce about as often as monogamous people do, and they break up with about as many people as monogamous people do. The only real difference in the rates is that poly people don\u2019t typically break up *in order to be with someone else*. That kinda defeats the purpose of being poly. If anything, we might have *slightly* less than 100% breakup rate of anyone who isn\u2019t a spouse, simply because we don\u2019t have to break up with them in order to get a spouse.\nSo, just looking at how often relationships end, poly relationships are probably roughly about as long-lived as monogamous ones. Poly people are people, after all. We still have to find compatible partners and we still grow and change over time which affects our relationships. Just like monogamous people.\nBut if you\u2019re looking at the *health* and *happiness* of poly relationships, or if you\u2019re looking at the quality of the *relationship skills* in poly relationships? Then no, I don\u2019t think poly relationships could function with such low standards.\nI believe poly relationships require much higher levels of relationship skills in order to both produce happiness in the participants and create longevity in relationships. But we also don\u2019t idolize longevity quite as strongly as monogamous people do either. We are slightly more likely to consider a relationship a \u201csuccess\u201d based on the happiness quotient over the longevity quotient. So with different metrics judging \u201csuccess\u201d, that\u2019s yet one more standard that poly relationships and monogamous relationships can\u2019t be compared to each other.\nNot only will I never be in a monogamous relationship again, I will also never date another monogamous *person* again. Even those who have spent the time and effort learning good relationship skills typically do not have the level of relationship skills that I require in my partners.\nIn fact, if I didn\u2019t happen to be heterosexual, I wouldn\u2019t even date straight *men* anymore either, since men, on average, have fewer skills than women simply because monogamous culture places the burden of maintaining a relationship on people socialized as women and men can, typically, coast along on their female partners\u2019 efforts. But since I\u2019m straight, I\u2019m kind of stuck with men for partners, so I\u2019m most certainly not going to waste my time with partners socialized as *monogamous* men.\nI am not a beginner relationship. The baseline of skills needed to maintain monogamous relationships are simply too basic to maintain a relationship with me.", "Do you think a polyamorous relationship could be as functioning as a 2-person relationship?\nI do not think that. I know from personal experience that polyamorous relationships can function just fine. In fact, for me, being in a polyamorous relationship is better than being part of a monogamous relationship.\nFor my wife and I, even when we were not really looking for other partners, the fact that we could made our relationship better."], "topic_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 9, 2020", "question_author": "Liya Elizabeth Jacob (\u0d32\u0d3f\u0d2f \u0d0e\u0d32\u0d3f\u0d38\u0d2c\u0d24\u0d4d\u0d24\u0d4d \u0d1c\u0d47\u0d15\u0d4d\u0d15\u0d2c\u0d4d)", "view_list": [25, 9, 9, 54, 255, 173], "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 3, 9, 1], "name_list": ["Butch Richter", "Lisa Wilcox", "Silvia Moreno", "Jae Harland", "Joreth Innkeeper", "Michael Benes"]}, "342": {"no_of_view": "2,596", "date_list": ["Apr 11, 2020", "Apr 5, 2020", "Apr 4, 2020", "Apr 4, 2020"], "question_title": "What does a narcissist do in a relationship?", "no_of_follower": 7, "respond_collected": 4, "ans_list": ["The same thing he did in your relationship with them.\nA leopard never changes their print\u2026just changes their prey", "Everything you ask them not to do or would much prefer that they didn\u2019t do\u2026", "Virtually nothing. I Have stated many times over that the secret to a successful relationship is compromise. When I say this it means for example, say I want to go fishing for awhile and want my wife to let me go with friends on a trip. How do I accomplish this feat? Well I know that there is a ballet or opera coming up she wants to attend but I don't because I think its boring but i need to think of her interest and needs and do the things she wants in order to get her to mutually meet my needs and interest. That is what I mean by a compromise, by not being selfish or self centered. I never compromise on a conflict or argument, especially if it means my morals or values are at stake. I Don't care how much it pisses off my wife. What I will do is listen carefully to what she says, get her opinion on the matter and offer my opinion. I was 100% behind both of those things. She is now disabled and cannot work. And again I am 100% ok with this.", "I don\u2019t really care about dating someone who has a job and makes money, but I do care about dating someone who has a sense of ambition and knows how to take tangible steps towards what they want, and that tends to coincide with having a career.\nThe trouble is, when you have two people together who are like that, it\u2019s often difficult for them to look up from their own work long enough to support each other, or sometimes, to take interest in what each other is even doing. Last night, I met with 6 friends on the basic ZOOM for about 45 minutes - we drank wine in our respective houses, discussed movies and shows that were binge-worthy. One person talked about how they made one thing a day to look forward to. My husband had been sliding towards depression, and he laughed a lot for the first time in awhile.\nI think that\u2019s the answer: use what you have to keep that flame burning. Schedule skyping sessions, zooming times with groups of friends you have in common, or those that you planned to introduce him to. We scheduled dinner/lunch with my daughter who lives in England - we\u2019d hoped to visit her fairly soon but that\u2019s off. They ate dinner while we ate lunch, and it was good! I got to know her husband\u2019s sister a bit more - she\u2019s shy and quiet, so it\u2019ll take awhile. I got to see them as a family, which made me feel good about how they\u2019re doing, and I\u2019d been worried, deep down, in the pit of my stomach. I have faith in her, really, but it\u2019s a mom thing. You worry. It comes with the territory.\nSo, tl:dr\u2026 Use the good side of social networking to build that foundation, and not just one on one, but with all of your friends, your family, and your special person. Make it a point, a focus, go through the hassle, the emailing, the reminding. Clean off the table. Light some candles. Pour the wine, or the good seltzer and fancy juice combo. Comb your hair. Change your shirt. Take a little pride in your appearance for that hour or so. S/he/they are worth it. Show that to them. You\u2019ll make it ok. Really.
